text: Muffled by the wet green forest. The very earth seems to tremble.
Darts out of a log, lifts itself on its hind legs and sni the air.

VOICES and SHOUTS, closer now, mix with the rumbling WAR  SOUNDS in a veritable symphony of violence and confusion. A DEAD AMERICAN GI lays splayed out, careless in death. A pair of SOLDIERS flash among the trees, running hunched over and low, and disappear into the gray blooms of SMOKE For a moment the forest takes a breath. Nothing but trembling leaves. Then - The RATTLE of a Jeep Coming closer in fits and starts, GRINDING through low ge A Willys MB appears, CRASHING through the undergrowth. It's driven by Private First Class KELLY ERNSWILER. Eighteen, if that. Not much meat on him. His insignias  indicate he's in the 29th Infantry. His face might be attractive, under other conditions. He pauses and pulls a map from the pocket of his M41 stan issue field jacket.
Where the hell are those Krauts?

To give himself courage, he SINGS Tommy Dorsey's "I'll Be Seeing You [in all the old familiar places]" while maneuv the Jeep through the bushes and rocks. He drives straight for a fallen LOG, GUNS the engine and  tries to go over it. The Jeep's FRONT WHEELS catch on the log. The BACK TIRES spin. Kelly gets out. Takes off his M1 combat helmet and wipes face. Assesses the situation. He grabs a BRANCH. Jams it under the wheel, trying to lev the Jeep free. When -- The STUTTER of a nearby MACHINE GUN startles him. The branch SNAPS against Kelly's weight. He slips and fal in the mud.
Shit.
Determined, he grabs his pack and carbine and sets off on foot through the forest.

Kelly strides purposefully out of the woods. Pauses again a split-rail fence beneath the innocent sun. Across the clearing stands a seemingly abandoned BARN. But not for long, as TWO GERMAN INFANTRYMEN appear around the corner of it. Kelly moves behind a tree to assess the situation. Unaware, the Germans smoke and talk. Kelly's too far away hear them but he watches their every move. They're relaxed, not as on guard as they should be. Their Karabiners rest slung across their backs.
Bingo.
Kelly focuses himself. Then he shoulders his carbine. Pulls out his dog tags and kisses them grimly.
"And so they buried Hector, breaker  of horses."

He takes his Smith & Wesson 1917 PISTOL from his pistol b and steps out into the SUNLIGHT FIELD in plain sight of t guards. Surely he knows they can see him. He must want them to se him. But they don't. Too busy passing nudie wallet photos. Halfway across the open grass, Kelly raises the pistol bu does not aim it. Just strides steadily closer, arms spread out, making him an easy target. Crazy as it seems, Private Kelly Ernswiler is trying to g himself killed.
Kelly pauses not twenty feet from the Germans, FIRES into the air and waves -- -- when from behind him comes a voice.
Eine maus findet den kase.

Kelly whips around to face a third German, the OFFICER. His pistol points right into the Officer's shocked pink y face. Point blank range. Only - Kelly doesn't fire. He just lowers the pistol. The German smiles.
Kill me Adolf.
Mien Prisoner!
The Infantrymen have recovered from their idle and come  running. One of them yanks Kelly's hands behind his back and pushe him into the barn roughly. Kelly doesn't struggle.
Hey, Siegfreid and Roy. What are you  waiting for? Kill me.
Kelly sits slumped in a chair, legs tied up. One of the  Germans shines a flashlight in his face. Kelly squints.
Come on you pussies. Let's get this  over with.
The German Officer produces a piece of paper and a founta pen.
(German accent) You will write your mother. Tell her  how you will die now.
Kelly takes the pen and examines it.
Genuine Third Reich issue, no less.  Nice work.
The Officer pokes the paper.
You will write. How you die alone.
My mother and I don't have that kind  of relationship.
(hisses) Write.
Kelly thinks about it for a minute - should he or shouldn he - but sighs and begins writing. After a few lines, the Officer snatches the paper away and passes it to an  Infantryman.
Enough. Now you will beg for your  life.
What don't you understand?
(interrupts sheepishly  in German accent) The protocol says we should -
The Officer wheels around and scowls at the speaker. He s to be getting a bit hysterical.
I am the fucking protocol. (to Kelly) Beg!
He and Kelly glare at each other. The Officer FIRES his Luger into the rafters.
Beg - for - your - life!
You got to be kidding me.
The Officer grabs his throat.
Silence. Now I have a little fun.
Kelly laughs. The officer slaps him. Kelly jerks away.
Now that's against the rules.
(sneers) There are no rules in war.
Suddenly another AMERICAN GI appears behind the German in the shadows. Only Kelly can see him. The GI motions to Kelly "keep tal while he gets into a better position with his M-1 rifle.
(to Officer) You've never killed anyone before,  have you?
I shower in the blood of my victims --
The GI shoots the two infantrymen who fall in exaggerated pain and commence death throes. Quick as a flash, the GI's Colt 1911 PISTOL is at the Ger Officer's neck, his M-1 in his other hand.
No wonder you smell so bad.
Don't shoot, please.
The GI's eyes widen. He looks at Kelly.
Will you look at the manners on this  guy? (to German) Remember to thank me when I kill  you.
No, really, not in the neck -
But the GI does anyway. The Officer SHRIEKS, grabs at his neck, and falls.
(to Kelly) You all right?
Yeah. My elaborate death scene wasn't  going anywhere anyway.
You want me to give you a minute?
That's okay. They'll get me  eventually. If you can't get killed  in a war, when can you?
That's right. Look on the bright  side.
The GI holds out his hand.
Bart. Bart Bowland.
Kelly takes the hand of the grinning all-American type gu About his own age, but BART takes up more space.
Kelly. Kelly Ernswiler.
Kelly?
(mimics) Bart?
I mean - that's Irish, right?

(from the floor, now  with a decidedly  American accent) Wow man, this is a really beautiful  scene and all, but I have to  interrupt. (to Bart) Why the fuck did you have to shoot  that cap so close to my neck? You  gave me a powder burn.
Listen you wienerschnitzel. You should  talk. You slapped me. I'm not your  bitch.
The Officer gets up and dusts off his uniform.
Well, what was that whole creepy  death wish thing about?
Well it didn't work, now did it?
(shrugs) Sometimes I get so caught up in the  moment.
And what was that ridiculous shit  about making me write to my mother?
The Officer grins.
Inspired, wasn't it?
Dude, you made him write to his  mother? Who are you, Dr. Phil?
(also with American  accent) Can we get up now?
Bart helps him up and checks his regulation-issue Timex.
Might as well. There's only an hour  left anyway.
The German Officer crosses his arms.
(to Kelly) Admit it. You were scared.
(snorts) Right.
Kelly gets up from the chair and falls over. His legs are still tied.
The DEAD GI gets up and walks off with the GERMANS and so other SOLDIERS, done for the day. Bart and Kelly walk back to the stranded Jeep.
That Willys yours?
Yup. Just got her. Three summers  packing out at Shop Rite.

Bart unfolds an entrenching tool from his belt and digs u the back wheels, building up dirt. Then he goes around to the front and puts his shoulder ag the hood. Bart rocks the Jeep while Kelly pumps the gas. The Jeep finally pulls free and SPRAYS Bart with mud.
My bad. Thanks though.
Kelly looks over his shoulder and starts backing away.
See you.
Bart stands there, dripping with mud, shocked. About a hundred feet away Kelly stops.
Well, come on.
Bart walks towards the Jeep. Kelly backs it up again.
I couldn't resist.
Bart climbs in.
Real funny, Ernswiler. You might  still get your chance to die today.

The customers are all REENACTORS. Some Yanks, some German a few Scottish and North African irregulars. "Boogie-Woog Bugle Boy" plays on the jukebox. Bart and Kelly sit in a booth together. Bart has an easy, confident manner and expansive gestures. Kelly eats hunch over, like someone might try and steal his food.
Character building? Those crazy guys  from Ann Arbor tied them to a dock.
(shrugs) That's what you get for invading  Wisconsin.
D-Day at Kenosha was nothing. At  Guadalcanal Chillicothe there was a  guy who actually injected himself  with malaria.
That's crazy.
They both eat for a minute.
Where do you live, anyway?
Shaker Heights.
That explains the death wish. Me  too. What street?
Penn Place.
(chewing) Hmm, don't know it.
It's not technically in Shaker Heights  - but I go to Shaker Heights High.
Pause. Kelly looks at Bart.
Langely Prep.
Sorry to hear that.
Well, I got kicked out of Shaker  Heights High because my birdhouse  came unglued in honors woodshop.
Of course. I would have gone to  Langely myself only my polo pony had  the fits.
Bart throws his napkin on his plate.
No matter. (raises his voice to  address the room) We're all soldiers here.
That's right./Here, here./ Whooping,  cheers, etc.
Kelly pulls up into the circular gravel drive. Bart's hou is fancy. A nice yard and a pool. Bart hops out.
You should come over some time. Service our lawnmower.
I would, but then I might soil my  croquet whites. You understand.
How bourgeois. Cheerio then.
Kelly watches Bart go into his house and smiles in spite himself.

Kelly's house is a also pretty nice, nothing to be ashame of. It is smaller and weirder. The flowers and bushes are overgrown and strange sculptures dot the yard, some leani at precarious angles. Kelly washes his Jeep in the driveway.
Kelly buffs the headlamps with a chamois. The Jeep looks  good as new. He pulls a canvas cover over it.
Sleep tight Hot Lips.
Kelly walks in on his dad ABE making sandwiches. A great pile of cheese and PB&J.
Sergeant Keller! How was the war?  Did we win?
Kelly doesn't smile at this. He looks at the sandwiches a puts his finger to his chin in a gesture so facetious it' downright angry.
Let me guess. Happy Meals for the  wavy gravy wellness center?
Abe grabs two pieces of bread from a loaf. He looks kind. bit ill-used by life. The phrase "rode hard and put away  wet" comes to mind.
As usual, your cynicism is refreshing.
He finishes that sandwich and adds it to the pile. Kelly pauses while opening the refrigerator. His back  tightens. He slams the door with his foot.
As usual, your cheerful optimism  makes me ill.
Abe pauses over a slice of bread only briefly. The hostil is nothing new.
(lightly) You should get that checked.
Kelly walks through the kitchen and out the back door.
Sure thing, doc. Say hello to Leif  Garrett for me.

Kelly opens the screen door and pokes his head in. A family of Chinese immigrants, the Lings, paints canvase at long worktables. There's a MOTHER, father MAO, grandmo XIOU-XIOU, SON and DAUGHTER. Finished canvases hang from the walls and lean in piles  against it. All of them are portraits of animals. Some ha on hats or clothes. Kelly's mom EVE shows grandmother XIOU-XIOU a few strokes with a paintbrush. Eve wears jeans. She's one of those young-looking mothers Kelly's friends would have crushes on. If he had any frie
(to Kelly) Son of Eve. You are very dirty.
(awkward) A rough charge. You know.
(to Kelly) Don't touch anything. We have to get  ready for the Starving Artist show. (to Xiou-Xiou) Now Nana, the gold has to be feathery,  not gloppy - see?
Eve demonstrates on the painting - a pair of monkeys in F court dress. Kelly looks over his mom's shoulder.
Now you try.
Grandmother Xiou-Xiou dabs at the painting.
(to Kelly) She loves the gold. Always overuses  it. And usually her touch is so light.
Gold is the color of the sun.
Eve moves along the row, stopping to look at the painting in progress.
You know why we never have anything  to eat in this house?
But Eve has stopped behind Mao's painting. She's not payi attention to Kelly.
Mao, what did we say about the eyes?
She gestures at the image of a horse done Santa Fe style, lots of pastels, very abstract. Mao looks at her quizzically.
More - empathy?
That's right. And didn't I tell you  to put in more cacti?
(shakes head) No, no more cacti. Too busy.  Simplicity is best.
His family nods in support of this rash aesthetic stateme Eve rolls her eyes.
Oh boy. I'm not having this battle  with you again.
Kelly breaks in.
Because your husband takes food from  his own family to feed every loser  druggie in Cleveland.
Eve moves down the line.
Well, you can always chip in here.  We're ordering pizza later.
At this the family nods and smiles to each other, pleased with the news.
No. Some people have to work later. (casual) Will you drop something off at the  dry cleaners for me tomorrow?
Eve looks up at him for the first time. Takes in his filt uniform.
Sweetie, you know what we said about  paying for the war things. Nothing's  changed.
It's the only thing I ever ask you  for --
Don't be dramatic.
But it's important to me.
Eve stops at Mother Ling's painting.
You're just going to have to find a  way to pay for it yourself then, I  guess. (to Mother Ling) No - not that way - the sky should  be stormier. Angry clouds.
Mother Ling looks up at Kelly, who's scowling. She smiles and nods, understanding.
Why do I bother?
Kelly leaves. Eve's busy talking.
More brown, less blue.
Kelly comes back in a grabs a sandwich off the pile.
Now Keller, who needs that sandwich  more - you or the daughter of a crack  addict trying to make a new life?
Kelly looks at him and bites into the sandwich.
How about the son of a heroin addict  trying to get ready for work?
Kelly leaves with the sandwich. Abe sighs and picks up mo bread.
That went well.

On the walls a poster for the Civil War miniseries next t one of Led Zeppelin. Some maps. A globe. Models of fighte planes and a set of old tin soldiers. Oh yeah, and his mom's ORIGINAL PAINTING, the one that st it all, this one signed by her - a very intense looking p rabbit glaring out of the canvas with huge eyes. He sits on the edge of the bed for a minute staring into  space before he peels off his muddy uniform piece by piec

Ah, the graveyard shift. Musak Steely Dan. Kelly unpacks cat food. Thousands and thousands of little cans of it. It's hard t keep the rows straight on the shelves. SARAH, the night cashier, stands at her register. She's p looking now but she'll be beautiful later when she figure out who she is. Not another soul in the store. Sarah wanders over to Kell aisle as if pulled by a magnet.
So how'd your battle go today? I  still don't understand how you could  reenact the Battle of the Bulge in  seventy-two degree weather. (plays with hair) Didn't all those guys freeze to death?
Kelly doesn't stop working. He's got a system.
Well, a Port-a-John fell over on a  couple of guys.
That's gross.
War is hell.
Kelly grabs another handful of cans.
Then why do you do it?
Kelly pauses. He puts two cans on the shelf very delibera
You're never more alive then when  facing simulated death.
Really? Maybe I should try it.
Kelly looks at her, thinks about this, and stands up.

You are William J. Stone of the 1st  Airborne, pinned down in Noville.  The Germans have the high ground and  they're shelling your position  heavily. (starts throwing cans) You're holed up in a stone barn.  Sustaining heavy casualties. Running  low on ammo. The cries of wounded  men fill the air like the cries of  hungry babies.
Sarah covers her head, huddled behind the boxes of cat fo dodging cans.

Your commanding officer gets hit in  the face, dies. At 1 p.m. you lose  radio contact with headquarters. If  you withdraw, the Germans will flank  the entire Allied forces arrayed  along Bastogne and break the front.  What do you do? What do you do?
Stop it!
Kelly goes back to stocking, satisfied.
Battle of Bulge, the Southern  Shoulder, December '44.
Sorry I asked.
Sarah stands up and starts to wander away but Kelly makes peace offering.
Hey. Want a snack? We got a whole  shipment in of busted Oreo's.
Sarah looks at her feet, considering whether or not to ac it.
I'll accidentally drop a couple pints  of milk and meet you over there.
Sarah and Kelly sit on milk crates, pass the cookies back and forth and get philosophical.
The frozen food woman came in with  her kids. They must eat out of those  little cardboard trays every night.  One of the kids looked like cardboard.
Do you know we stock more flavors of  cat food than we do baby food?
No.
Sixteen flavors of baby food including  the toddler meals-in-ajar, thirty- one flavors of cat food.
He fishes for a cookie.
Next time you should tell that woman  to buy her kid some cat food.
An ANGRY WOMAN pushes open the swinging door of the backr with her loaded shopping cart.
Is this store open? I've been waiting  up front. If the store's closed, it  shouldn't have a sign that says twenty- four hours.
Sarah gets up. Kelly stays right where he is, finishing a cookie.
Sorry about that.
I have a lot of coupons and I don't  want to be here when they expire.
(to Sarah) Charge her double for everything.
Sarah smiles and hurries away.

Kelly walks down the hall with his army-issue BACKPACK sl over one shoulder. Besides a serious case of bedhead, he  looks normal. No one says hi to him as he makes his way to his locker. As he twirls the combination and opens it, he notices LAN short and wide, built like a tank, prematurely balding, a his girlfriend BRIDGET embracing a few lockers down. They kiss raunchily, their tongues darting in and out of  each other's mouths. Lance sees Kelly looking and stops kissing.
What the fuck are you looking at, GI  Jane?
Kelly shakes his head and gets a book out of his locker.
No really, what makes you think you  can look at me?
I honestly didn't know it was you. I  thought it was a free preview of the  Spice Channel.
That's pretty funny. You got dental  insurance?
Kelly closes his locker and walks away. Bridget wipes her mouth guiltily. Lance shakes his head and pulls Bridget to him, grinding pelvis against hers.
Stop it.
She walks away.
What? What?

The lights are off in history class. The teacher MR. NORMAN shows slides on the Civil War. The more we see the clearer it becomes that they are his own  photos from a vacation spent visiting the memorials. Mr. Norman smiles out at his class in shot after shot. He clicks the remote and a photo of his WIFE, crouched ov and wearing shorts, drinking from a garden hose appears o screen.
Whoops!
He hurries through to the next slide. It doesn't matter anyway. Everyone is almost asleep. Except Kelly, who becomes increasingly irritated the more Mr. Norman talks.
And here, at Gettysburg, the ranks  of Union soldiers fought bravely on.  They were willing to give their lives  so that others might be free.
Kelly shifts in his seat.
Is there a problem Mr. Ernswiler?
No.
But Mr. Norman doesn't start talking again. He waits, looking at Kelly, smiling blandly. Until the si becomes uncomfortable. And Kelly gets mad.

Come on. Isn't this analysis a tad  simplistic? I mean, maybe for a second  grade history class, sure - but to  insist on still characterizing the  Civil War as some moral struggle?  The soldiers were drafted - the only  ones who had to fight were the ones  who couldn't afford to pay their way  out. (losing it) Why don't you talk about the Draft  Riots? Where are your slides for  that?
Fresh flowers and a crocheted tissue box hoodie make the  place cozy. Kelly sits across the desk from PRINCIPAL HOLMSTEAD, a we groomed woman with a gentle talk show host demeanor.
What gives you the idea that you can  or ought to question the curriculum?
Kelly doesn't move. He's not into this.
Or question your teacher?
I know. I mean, who ever heard of a  classroom dialog? Not Socrates.
Ms. Holmstead is exasperated, but she likes him in spite herself. He's a smart cookie. She's got to change her  strategy. She leans back in her chair.
Kelly, you're a very bright boy. But  you're making some serious mistakes.
I don't need to. Everyone else makes  them for me.
Her chair SQUEAKS as she leans forward and looks at Kelly intently.
This anger must be masking a lot of  hurt.
I was wondering what the tissues  were for.
Holmstead tries again. She looks down at his file.
I see you're not going to college  next year. What are your plans?
Kelly shrugs. Holmstead searches his face for any clues.
How do I get through to you?
Advertisers use status and sex to  appeal to my demographic.
She shakes her head and swings her chair towards the wind and gazes out at the front walkway of the school. Her fac clears. Something's clicked.
I think we can come up with a  punishment which might actually be  more of an opportunity for you to  realize your true potential.
School's been out for a while. The first rush had already left. Kelly comes down the front steps and starts across the pa lot to his Jeep. Lance steps out from behind an SUV and intercepts him.
You upset Bridget.
Kelly hardly stops walking.
Give me a break.
You need to apologize.
What are you going to do, make out  with me?
Lance runs and grabs Kelly's backpack.
Why are you fucking with me? You  little fucker. Want to play, fuckface?
You just used fuck as a verb, noun,  and adjective. Impressive.
Kelly tries to start walking again but Lance has hold of  him.
Let's see what Beetle Bailey's got  in his knapsack.

Lance grabs Kelly's arm and yanks it back. Kelly still se unconcerned. Suddenly he pulls away, but Lance keeps hold of his backp Lance holds the backpack up next to his head and points a it, gleeful. Lance walks away towards his car. Kelly runs after him. Lance holds Kelly off easily with one hand and throws the backpack into his SUV. They STRUGGLE for a minute, until  Lance pushes Kelly away, gets in the car. Kelly runs next to the car and pounds on the window as La drives off. Finally, Kelly gives up. Lance turns out of the parking l and HONKS the horn. Kelly shakes his head.
Rim job.
Kelly sifts through a pile of backpacks looking for a  replacement. From his post behind the counter, Bart sees and comes over.
Kelly. Hey.
You work here?
Just a couple days a month, to get a  heads-up on the latest stuff. What  are you doing?
Looking for a backpack.
Is that all? Don't bother. I have a  couple extras at home. I could give  you one if you want.
(beat) Sure, I guess.
Kelly stands a bit awkwardly waiting for Bart to get the from the desk to open the door in the corner. The door fi swings open.
Bart and Kelly stand between shelves piled high with war  memorabilia. Uniforms in vacu-pac sealed bags, weapons in shoeboxes, cannonballs and tattered and gunsmoke-darkened flags.
Very impressive.
My dad's real into hoarding.
Kelly holds up a flask in a leather case.
What's this?
Grant's field flask.
Wow. Your dad should meet my history  teacher. He sent me to the principal's  office today for questioning his G- rated interpretation of the Civil  War.
Forget him.
I would, but now the principal's  making me give a speech on the Civil  War at an assembly.
(laughing in sympathy  and amusement) What is he, some kind of sadist?
She thinks she's doing me a favor.
Jesus, she must think you're really  screwed up. Are you?
Depends on who you ask. Everyone's  got an opinion.
(grabs box) Take this. That'll shut them up.
Bart opens the long box. Nestled inside is a leg bone wit foot attached to it.
Stonewall Jackson's.
Yeah right.
Can you imagine that? Losing your  leg and getting back up on your horse?  Unbelievable. What balls.
Kelly nods. That is balls.
He's got so much crap crammed in  here he doesn't even notice when  it's missing. I saw a backpack in  here somewhere.
Bart puts down the box carelessly and paws through the pi
Bart and Kelly sit at the kitchen table drinking sodas,  waiting for MINNIE, the housekeeper, to finish making the dinner.
I thought he had a couple.
I'd feel weird taking one out of the  tomb of Tutenkamen anyway.
Trust me, you shouldn't. (burps) Where'd your old one go?
I lost it.
How?
A pause. Kelly decides to tell him.
Someone took it.
You let someone take it?
I didn't let him. I told off some  idiot --
Sounds like your mouth gets you into  trouble a lot.
I'm telling you, it's not me, it's  the world.
TABBY, Bart's older sister comes in. She's older. Definitely in college, if not out. And total shockingly beautiful. Otherworldly.
Tabby, this is Kelly.
(to Kelly) Don't give him any money, whatever  you do.
Shut up.
All these little old ladies are  looking for him in Arizona. He took  their retirement money and bought  defective bazookas with it.
Kelly laughs. And looks at Tabby more closely.
Very funny. We're paying attention  to you, are you happy now?
Finally, my life is complete. Fait  accompli.
(to Tabby) Minnie's making sloppy joes. Want  one?
Sloppy joe? Sloppy no.
She opens the fridge and gets a yogurt.
I have to go take a shower. Will you  call me when Miner gets here?
Tabby leaves. Kelly's distracted.
Who's Miner?
The fiance.
Bart rolls his eyes, indicating what he thinks of good ol Miner. Kelly nods, doesn't say anything.
Listen, I'm going to the flea market  on Saturday. I have a line on a couple  dealers. You could get a backpack  there.
Kelly glances at the door Tabby left from.
Oh yeah? Flea market, land of  bargains.
Especially if you know who to talk  to.
Kelly looks at Bart with suspicion -- and respect.

Kelly hops out of his Jeep and walks towards the front of the school. Lance is there, hanging out with Bridget and some of his Magnon FRIENDS. He wears a WW II CAP, overseas airborne style, obviously  Kelly's.
Hey fuckface. Like my new hat? I  just joined the Boy Scouts.
The Cro-Magnons grunt approvingly at this witty repartee.
If you stay in it long enough, maybe  you'll get your fudgepacker badge.
Ooh. The Cro-Magnons laugh at Lance and EGG him on - "You gonna take that?"/"He just called you a fag", etc. Lance frowns and grabs Kelly.
You're a regular Howie Mandel.
Still holding on to him with one arm, he SLAPS Kelly hard across the face with the other. Kelly's knees give a bit. Lance holds him up.
Lance!
Lance looks over at her and releases Kelly.
Okay babe. (to Kelly) One day you and me will be alone.  And won't that be nice?
Kelly is hurt but covering.
Too bad my mom won't let me date  yet.
Kelly frowns and adjusts his clothes. Tries to re-wet the dry inside of his mouth with his tongue. He turns slowly and trudges up the stairs. Sarah has been watching the whole thing from the door.
Why do you mess with him?
You're right. I should give him a  break.
Kelly watches TV in the living room. His cheek has a nice bruise on it. Eve enters.
Oh, Kelly, you're home. Good. I need  you to go to the art supply store  for me.
Kelly looks at the TV.
Get Abe to do it.
Eve goes to her purse and rifles through it to find her  wallet.
He was going to but he had to go  lead a meeting at Care House.
What a surprise.
I'll make it up to you.
Where have I heard that before?
Eve sighs.
When are you going to give me a break?
Kelly jabs at the remote.

Let me think - maybe when I finally  forget every single word of The Little  Mermaid soundtrack I'd listen to in  the car waiting for him to score.  No, probably when I don't prepare  myself before I go into the bathroom,  expecting to find him passed out on  the floor.
Eve waits through this.

Actually, you know what? I know I'll  be able to put it all behind me when  I go away to college. (slaps his forehead,  pretend remembering) Only, I can't go because someone  spent my college fund on Mexican  Black Tar. So looks like I'll have  to try to forget at Shop Rite, where  I'll be working for the rest of my  life.
You're right. You have every reason  to crawl into the corner and give  up. But please just get me some paints  first.
Eve comes over to Kelly. He sighs and puts his hand out.
What do you need?
She gives him the money.
We need burnt sienna, cadmium red,  and midnight blue. Two tubes of blue. (looks at him) What happened to your face?
She puts her hand up but he moves away from it.
Forget it.

Kelly looks through the paints, picking out tubes. He loo up and sees Tabby browsing the paintbrushes. He's suddenly nervous. He knocks over a few cans of thinn Almost leaves. Instead, he gathers his courage, goes to the display oppo hers and waits to catch her eye.
They're having a sale on glitter.
It takes Tabby a second to recognize him.
Oh, hello. What happened to you?
(shrugs) Tennis injury.
Tabby looks at him suspiciously like she's not sure wheth to believe him. Tabby finishes with the mediums and moves onto the paints Kelly follows her, staying in the opposite aisle.
You paint?
Well, you see... That's a difficult  question.
How so?

I don't really feel comfortable  calling anything done since the  Renaissance "painting." We might  have a more experimental interaction  with the picture plane, but our skills  have suffered from it.
In spite of herself, Tabby laughs at this. This gives Kel more confidence. He leans over the aisle to see what she' looking at.

Because you know why. Just go home.

Kelly finally looks up at Bart and nods. A Town Car pulls up. Tabby gets out in her wedding dress. Has there even been more glorious woman? Will there ever be again? Her MAID OF HONOR leads her around to the side of the chu Kelly watches every step.
She looks beautiful. Tell her - give  her my congratulations.
Kelly walks off. Bart watches him go.
Kelly sits on the edge of the bed, head in hands. He sees the torn rabbit painting. After a minute, he pick it up and looks at it.
Xiou-Xiou sits painting. Kelly enters with the rabbit.
Oh! Son of Eve. You startled me.
Grandma Ling. Can you fix this?
She examines it and takes out a wet sponge. She wipes it  across the back of the canvas.
Your mom made it for you. I can fix  it.
She works silently for a minute. Kelly watches her. She c a small piece of canvas to repair the hole.
Did you come here to work on your  own stuff? Don't waste your time on  this.
I never waste time.
She turns the painting over and gets out some paints to t it up.
See. Everything can be mended.
You're trying to tell me something,  aren't you?
Oh no. I could not tell you anything.
Eve sleeps in a chair next to Abe, in bed sleeping. He lo pale but otherwise fine. Kelly stands in the doorway, still in his uniform. Abe comes to and sees him standing there.
Hey. Kelly.
Hey dad. How you feeling?
Not bad.
They gave me some stitches downstairs. (points to eyebrow) Three.
Did you get punched?
A couple times, actually.
I know the feeling. Come on in and  watch some television. Don't worry,  this one's bolted to the wall. As  you can see, my reputation precedes  me.
Kelly comes into the room and sits in a chair.
Any battles this weekend?
A few.
Busy, busy.
Abe and Kelly look up at the television in the corner.
Answer me this: how come no one ever  reenacts the Vietnam War?
It'd be pretty depressing, wouldn't  it?
I guess it would.
Both continue to look up at the television.
Plus that, you'd have to have  protesters and stuff.
Folks dressed up like your mom and  me. People reenacting fleeing to  Canada, burning draft cards. I guess  that would ruin the spirit of the  thing, now wouldn't it?
I could make it work.
Abe looks at Kelly.
I bet you could.
Kelly nods. Eve wakes up.
Kelly, is that you?
You were expecting some one else?
Kelly and Eve get snacks from the vending machine.
He looks good.
Eve looks at Kelly, her face full of love and sadness.
He looks just like you.

Kelly nods slowly, taking this in. And it is finally too  much. He breaks down and cries. For the fear and the misplaced  rage, the fights and the stubbornness. But finally, relief. They walk back down the hall together. Eve reaches out an puts her hand on Kelly's neck.
Kelly rides his bike past the house and stops when he see the car packed up in front. Bart comes out with a box of stuff.
Hey.
Hey. You going away already?
Yeah. The have this intensive summer  orientation thing.
Is that good?
Bart puts the box in the car.
Well, it's optional, but dad thinks  it would be "a good way to meet  people."
He's probably right.
He usually is.
They stand there.
Well, go Big Green.
Kelly gives him a little ra-ra with one hand. Bart smiles Kelly's been doing his research.
Thanks.
Kelly lifts his foot up to the pedal of his bike.
Have fun. And get laid, will ya?
Bart laughs a little and shakes his head. Kelly is gone. Harrison comes out.
Is that everything?
Everything you'd let me bring.
Harrison checks the ties on the roof.
Give me a break.
Kelly stocks shelves. There's a NEW GIRL working the register. Kelly sees SARAH come in. He follows her to the bakery.
Hey.
Hey.
Sarah picks some bagels.
How come you don't work here anymore?  The Electro-shopper's getting rusty.
I've got a summer internship at an  ad agency.
Fancy.
It's all right, I guess.
No, it's great.
Kelly moves around to her other side, closer.
Hey -
Sarah moves away. Once bitten twice shy and all that.
When are you going to get a real  job?
I don't know. Probably when I figure  out something better to do.
You can't be a stock boy your whole  life.
Sarah walks to the front of the store. Kelly walks with h
Yeah I can. I mean, I probably won't,  but I could.
Sarah turns to him at the checkout aisle.
Well, it was good seeing you.
Um.
What?
Remember that presentation I told  you never to ask me about again?
Kelly stands in the front of the room, pointing to a batt plan with large arrows drawn on it. Charlie, Mr. Norman, Principal Holmstead, Eve and Sarah s among other OLD SOLDIERS.
Lee arrayed his defenses over here.  Only this time, Grant was ready for  him.
Kelly keeps talking. Many of the OLD SOLDIERS sleep.
(to old soldier 2) This is boring.
Yeah. Let's see that slide of the  wife again.
Sarah, Kelly, and Eve play dominos with Charlie and Mr.  Norman.
(to Charlie) Remarkable, remarkable. And they  never knew?
The real kicker was moving those  cutouts of tanks around. The thought  we had a whole regiment over there,  but it was just a couple of us and  those Hollywood props.
That's amazing. Art playing a part  in war.
You're damned right. We practically  won the thing right there. (eyeing Sarah and Eve  with approval) Now this is more like it. Anyone  care to place a wager on the table?
Kelly tries to gesture to Sarah "no."
If you think it would be more fun.
I can't imagine having more fun that  I am now.
Mr. Norman smiles at the group.
You're never been to a French  whorehouse, I take it.
I have.
Oh, my.
Eve waits while Kelly and Sarah walk out to Sarah's car. Kelly helps Sarah into it and closes the door for her.
I still don't understand how you did  that.
I spent my summers with my grandma  in the Catskills. She didn't give me  any spending money. (shrugs) So I played the bones for ice cream.
She pulls away. He watches her go.
Hot damn.
